strategy: Apply a Random Forest with mutual information-based feature selection to identify the most informative predictors, then use a log transformation on the target variable to stabilize variance and improve model convergence. Additionally, introduce time-based splits if the data has temporal structure (e.g., based on year of sale), ensuring no data leakage. This approach leverages ensemble robustness and feature relevance without relying on gradient-based optimization.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.feature_selection import SelectKBest, f_regression
from sklearn.preprocessing import FunctionTransformer
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
validation = pd.read_csv('data/validation.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Log transform target variable to stabilize variance
train['SalePrice'] = np.log1p(train['SalePrice'])
target = train['SalePrice']

# Drop irrelevant columns
drop_cols = ['Id', 'PoolQC', 'Alley', 'MiscFeature', 'Fence', 'FireplaceQu', 'PoolArea', 'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']
train = train.drop(columns=drop_cols)
test = test.drop(columns=drop_cols)

# Handle missing values
for col in train.columns:
    if train[col].dtype == 'object':
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].mode()[0])
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].median())
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].median())

# One-hot encode categorical variables
train = pd.get_dummies(train, drop_first=True)
test = pd.get_dummies(test, drop_first=True)

# Align columns between train and test
common_cols = train.columns.intersection(test.columns)
train = train[common_cols]
test = test[common_cols]

# Feature selection using mutual information (via f_regression as proxy)
X = train.drop(columns=['SalePrice'])
y = target

# Use SelectKBest to select top 30 features based on f_regression (replacing mutual info with a robust alternative)
selector = SelectKBest(f_regression, k=30)
X_selected = selector.fit_transform(X, y)
selected_features = X.columns[selector.get_support()]

# Create new dataset with selected features
X_final = X[selected_features]
X_val = validation[selected_feature

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.feature_selection import SelectKBest, f_regression
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
validation = pd.read_csv('data/validation.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Log transform target variable to stabilize variance
train['SalePrice'] = np.log1p(train['SalePrice'])

# Drop irrelevant columns
drop_cols = ['PoolQC', 'Alley', 'MiscFeature', 'Fence', 'FireplaceQu', 'PoolArea', 'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']
train = train.drop(columns=drop_cols)
test = test.drop(columns=drop_cols)

# Handle missing values
for col in train.columns:
    if train[col].dtype == 'object':
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].mode()[0])
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].median())
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].median())

# One-hot encode categorical variables
train = pd.get_dummies(train, drop_first=True)
test = pd.get_dummies(test, drop_first=True)

# Align columns between train and test
common_cols = train.columns.intersection(test.columns)
train = train[common_cols]
test = test[common_cols]

# Ensure 'SalePrice' is not in features
if 'SalePrice' in train.columns:
    X = train.drop(columns=['SalePrice'])
    y = train['SalePrice']
else:
    X = train
    y = train['SalePrice']

# Feature selection using mutual information (via f_regression as proxy)
selector = SelectKBest(f_regression, k=30)
X_selected = selector.fit_transform(X, y)
selected_features = X.columns[selector.get_support()]

# Create new dataset with selected features
X_final = X[selected_features]
X_val = validation[selected_features]
test_final = test[selected_features]

# Time-based split: spl

from sklearn.feature_selection import SelectKBest, f_regression
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
validation = pd.read_csv('data/validation.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Log transform target variable to stabilize variance
train['SalePrice'] = np.log1p(train['SalePrice'])

# Drop irrelevant columns
drop_cols = ['PoolQC', 'Alley', 'MiscFeature', 'Fence', 'FireplaceQu', 'PoolArea', 'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']
train = train.drop(columns=drop_cols)
test = test.drop(columns=drop_cols)

# Handle missing values
for col in train.columns:
    if train[col].dtype == 'object':
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].mode()[0])
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].mode()[0])
    else:
        train[col] = train[col].fillna(train[col].median())
        test[col] = test[col].fillna(test[col].median())

# One-hot encode categorical variables
train = pd.get_dummies(train, drop_first=True)
test = pd.get_dummies(test, drop_first=True)

train = train[common_cols]
test = test[common_cols]

if 'SalePrice' in train.columns:

    y = train['SalePrice']
